As Ostanin writes, “Amztarakhan (more correct Ashtarakhan, Aztarakan) — the capital of the Astrakhanskii khanate, which arose during the disintegration of the Golden Horde, located not far from the Itil’” (27). According to Boguslawski, “old Tatar names of today’s Astrakhan” (“Annotations” 236).

explanatory Russia location
millipedes

Myriapods (Ancient Greek μυρίος meaning “ten thousand” + πούς meaning “foot”) of the subphylum Myriapoda. Includes millipedes and centipedes Animal motif.

motif
begging the hiccups to move over to the submissive passion-bearers Fedot and Yakov

A reference to the saying “Икота, икота, уйди на Федота, с Федота на Якова, с Якова на всякого” (Hiccups, hiccups, go to Fedot, from Fedot to Yakov, from Yakov to everyone). This proverb derives from the folk belief that hiccups (a disease or demonic invasion) could be passed from one person to another. This hiccup (and the barrel further below) develops also the recurrent drinking theme. Although incidentally mentioned here at the end of chapter 2 through the allusion to a folkloric rhyme against hiccups (R163/E25), toward the end of the novel, Krylobyl, Ilya’s “spiritual” guide, is addressed by the poet in Note XXX (R206/E266), by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220), and by Ilya in chapter 17 as “Fedot Fyodorov” (R279/E227). The now dated name Fedot (or Fedoty, Theodotus) derives from the Greek and means “given by God (or Gods).” His patronymic (“son of Fyodor”) stresses this divine connection, as Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.”

explanatory language theme intertextuality intratextuality folklore
Yakov

Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character structure
barrel of the narrative

An image used several times in the novel to refer to the process and form of writing. See R206/E99 and R280/E230. Near the end of the novel, Note XXXV describes putting a bung back on a bottle of vodka (R272/E214). Alcohol theme.

intratextuality theme structure
bung

A small peg or plug used to seal a cask or barrel. Alcohol theme.

explanatory theme
philosophized

A word (verb, adjective) used repeatedly with connection to Yakov. See R163/E25, R189/70, R197/E86, R274/E219, and R277/E223.

intratextuality character
Vita sine libertate nihil

Latin: Life without freedom is nothing.

foreign
Vita sine libertate nihil, he philosophized, vivere est militare

Elena Kravchenko reads Yakov’s musings as an allusion to Mikhail Lermontov’s hero Pechorin in A Hero of Our Time who says, “I am prepared for all sacrificies except this one [marriage]; I’ll bet my life, even my honor, twenty times on cards […] but I won’t sell my freedom” (The Prose 68).

intertextuality
vivere est militare

Latin: To live is to fight. A borrowing from Seneca the Younger, the Roman Stoic philosopher, statesman, dramatist, from his Moral Letters to Lucilius (96.5).

foreign intertextuality
He was not fresh and not young

Yakov. A reference to the novel’s epigraph from Boris Pasternak’s Doctor Zhivago: “The young man was a hunter.” It may also recall Yesenin’s famous (last) words too: “В этой жизни умирать не ново, / Но и жить, конечно, не новей” (To die, in this life, is not new, / And living’s no newer, of course).

intratextuality intertextuality
Жить

This sentence is constructed according to a complex system (infinitive and additional verbs): zhit’ […] byt’ […] zhit’, byt’ i videt’ […] zhit’-byt’ […] zhit’-byt’ […]. It is also resonant with the list of verbs that comes as an epigraph in A School for Fools: “To chase, to hold, and to rotate / To hear, to see, and to offend, / To run, to breathe, likewise to hate, / and to endure, and to depend. – Russian verbs that represent well-known exception of the rules, rhythmically organized for easier memorization.”

register/style intertextuality self-reference
Жить

The narration in the chapters concerning Yakov are characterized by their more poetic style. This narrator, for instance, frequently uses infinitives, which evoke the eternal quality and endless time of the novel’s setting.

Для глав, касающихся Якова, характерен более поэтический стиль повествования. Например, этот автор часто использует инфинитивы, подчеркивающие эффект вечности и нескончаемости времени действия романа.

language register/style
глубоким галошам

Alliteration (g, l).

Аллитерация (г, л).

sound stylistic device
глубоким галошам в пору разлива глубоких

Repetition with a variatio in the case (glubokim - glubokich),

Повторение с изменением падежа (глубоким - глубоким).

rhythm
галошам

Galoshes. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

Резиновая обувь. Мотив обуви.

motif intertextuality
мусолить

Colloquial: to slabber, to soil, to drool over, to spend too much time over.

Разговорное: затягивать, копаться, возиться, тратить слишком много времени на что-то.

register/style
мусолить жирно-зеленый лист

Sokolov comments: “You may have noticed that cats, while strolling in the garden or in the woods, find some nice-tasting grasses and chew them. Specialists say that cats do this instinctively: those grasses are healing. Humans, though perhaps not all, have the same instinct. In our childhood and adolescence, it is evident. Once in nature, a child strives to pick up a leaf of grass or a tree and chew it, this action is involuntary. In adolescence and later we do it less often, but we cannot completely get rid of the habit of chewing something. If there is no plant at hand, we chew a pencil, a paintbrush, a pen. This helps creativity, becomes an integral part of it. Chewing or munching something, we involuntarily masticate, i.e. salivate this object. Alas, it is not quite aesthetic, but we cannot change this state of affairs. The phrase ‘to soil the dark-green leaf’ contains no hint of something more complicated; it is merely a glimpse, a small aspect of a specific past” (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

Соколов комментирует: “Возможно, вы замечали, что кошки, гуляя в саду или в лесу, находят какие-то приятные на вкус травинки и жуют их. Специалисты говорят, что кошки поступают так инстинктивно: те травинки целебны. Людям, пусть, может быть, и не всем, присущ тот же инстинкт. В нашем детстве и отрочестве он проявляется со всей очевидностью. Оказавшись на природе, ребенок норовит сорвать лист травы или дерева и пожевать его, это действие безотчетно. В юности и позже мы делаем это реже, но полностью изжить в себе привычку что-нибудь пожевать не удается. Если под рукой нет растения, грызем карандаш, кисть, перо. Это помогает творчеству, становится его неотъемлемой частью. Грызя или жуя что-либо, мы невольно мусолим, то есть слюнявим данный предмет. Увы, это не вполне эстетично, но изменить такое вот положение дел мы не в силах. Фраза ‘мусолить жирно-зеленый лист’ не содержит намека на нечто более сложное, это просто промельк, малый аспект конкретного прошлого” (личное сообщение, 7 июня 2023).

explanatory
лист

Leaf or page. In the second meaning, the narrator might be suggesting spending too much time on writing and reading.

Лист растения или лист бумаги. Во втором значении, автор, возможно, намекает на избыток времени, проводимого за чтением или письмом.

explanatory language
лопух

A plant used in traditional medicine. Plant motif.

motif
Жить-быть

It may recall the typical opening of fairytales: “zhili-byli” (once upon a time).

Возможная отсылка к стандартному началу сказок: “жили-были”.

intertextuality register/style
по мере змеенья зимы меняться оттенкам ее слюдяных чешуйчатых крыльев

Sokolov comments: “Winter, with its snowstorms and blizzards, surprised me with its snaky habits from an early age. And not only me. See for example the beginning of a famous poem by Fet. If winter snakes and has wings, then it is nothing else but a flying kite, and those wings only appear to be made of mica, in fact they are made of ice” (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

Соколов комментирует: “Зима с ее поземками и вьюгами сызмала удивляла меня своими змеиными повадками. И не только меня. Вот начало знаменитого стихотворения Фета: “Какая грусть! Конец аллеи / Опять с утра исчез в пыли, / Опять серебряные змеи / Через сугробы поползли”. Если зима змеится и у нее есть крылья, значит она не что иное, как летучий змей, причем эти крылья лишь кажутся слюдяными, на самом деле они ледяные” (личное сообщение, 7 июня 2023).

explanatory intertextuality
мере змеенья зимы меняться

Alliteration (m, z).

Аллитерация (м, з).

sound stylistic device
слюдяных

Mica: Silicate minerals that may be divided into thin plates. They can resembles sheets of books, which corresponds with the preceding line in which the narrator mentions leaves/sheets. Also mentioned in Note XIII (R199/E88).

Слюды: группа минералов-алюмосиликатов, обладающих слоистой структурой. Могут напоминать страницы книги, что согласуется с упоминанием листа несколькими строками выше. Изображено ниже:

Также встречается в Записке XIII (R199/E88).

explanatory intratextuality
переливаются перламутрово

Alliteration (p, r, l).

Аллитерация (п, р, л).

sound stylistic device
перепело́

Regional, dialectal: membrane, cover.

Региональное, диалектное: оболочка, пленка.

register/style
Марии

Another name given to Orina, the central female figure in the novel. In the chapters devoted to Yakov, she becomes his mother, thus the characters enact a variation on the Oedipal myth. Hanna Kolb writes: “She is a Rossiia-mater’ (little mother Russia) (65) in eighteenth-century language […] She is the Volga, the wolf-river which gives them crayfish to eat and water to drink, a stone under their heads, but also a stone around their necks. In each of the only two women’s names that occur in the text, Orina and Mariia, may be heard “rodina” (native land), as well as “mat’ (mother). Mariia is Iyakov’s mother and the mother of God, about whom Il’a [sic] speaks in his Christmas sermon […], both a mother goddess and the Mother of God. The lover Orina is raised in the figure of the Lady to sainthood, to the role of Blok’s simultaneously life-giving […] and death-giving “neponiatnaia neznakomka” (115)” (204). Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

Еще одно имя, присвоенное Орине, центральной женской фигуре романа. В главах, посвященных Якову, она становится его матерью, участвуя, таким образом, в воспроизведении героями мифа о Эдипе. Х. Кольб пишет: “Она — Россия-матерь (65) в языке XVIII века […] Она — Волга, волчья река, которая дает им речных раков в пищу и воду для утоления жажды, камень под их головой, но также и камень у них на шее. В каждом из единственных двух женских имен в тексте, Орина и Мария могут читаться как “родина” или “мать”. Мария — мать Якова, а также матерь Божья, о которой Илья говорит в своей воскресной проповеди […], богиня материнства и Божья Матерь. Любовница Орина причисляется в образе Дамы к лику святых, к блоковской роли дарящей жизнь […] и смерть “непонятной незнакомке” (115)” (Kolb 204).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
трубить в пастуший рожок

Like a shepherd, Maria gives signals and calls, directing traffic at the railway station. Another connection to the central “between dog and wolf” metaphor.

Подобно пастуху, Мария посылает сигналы и предупреждения, регулируя движение на желехнодорожной станции. Очередная отсылка к центральной метафоре романа “Между собакой и волком”.

character theme explanatory
на железной дороге

Like Orina, Maria works at the railway station, directing trains. The symbol of the train station is central in Sokolov’s work. Railroad theme.

Как и Орина, Мария работает регулировщицей на железнодорожной станции.

location character theme explanatory
север в пятнадцати минутах спокойной ходьбы на закат. Ходьбы по аллее, восставленной перпендикуляром к насыпи — на восход. На юго

The four cardinal directions: north, west, east, south.

Четыре стороны света: север, запад, восток, юг.

explanatory
закат

West. Again, twilight — the central metaphor and time of the novel. Rising and falling are crucial to the novel, as characters struggle to escape their surroundings and overcome their temptations in the Russian backwoods.

Запад. Вновь, сумерки — центральная метафора и время действия романа. Подъем и падение являются неотъемлемыми частями романа, ведь герои тщетно пытаются избежать своего окружения и преодолеть искушения в глуши русских лесов.

time theme
насыпи

An embankment used in railway construction to address changes in level.

Искусственное возвышение из земли, применяемое в железнодорожностроении, чтобы избежать перепада высот на пути. Изображено ниже:

explanatory
восход

East. Rising and falling are central to the novel, as characters struggle to escape their surroundings and overcome their temptations in the Russian backwoods.

Восток. Подъем и падение являются неотъемлемыми частями романа, ведь герои тщетно пытаются избежать своего окружения и преодолеть искушения в глуши русских лесов.

theme time
над городом, вследствие значительных дымочадных, коверкающих горизонт, работ всегда иметься в наличии выбору вяленых и копченых туч

Metaphoric visual-“scented” description of the sky above the city, full of “smokey” clouds as a result of burning wood in the houses.

Метафорическое визуально-“обонятельное” описание неба над городом, полного “вяленых и копченых” туч из-за дыма городских очагов.

poetic device language register/style
Рисовать

Much in the chapters devoted to Yakov, his life, and his thoughts consists of ekphrasis—the literary device of describing in words a visual work of art—and other combinations of different genres and media. Here, for instance, the reader is asked to imagine the events of the chapter coming to life as if being painted before their eyes.

Значительную часть глав, касающихся Якова, его жизни и мыслей, составляет эксфразис — описание произведения искусства литературном тексте — и другие сочетания жанров и сфер. Здесь, например, читателю предлагается представить события главы как если бы они были нарисованы у него перед глазами.

explanatory structure
сотрудников почт — почтальонов

Synonims.

Синонимия.

explanatory
сотрудников почт — почтальонов, охваченные отчаянием и листопадом

Amf5+Dak1+Amf2; repetition (ch, t).

Амф5+Дак1+Амф2; повтор (ч, т).

metrical pattern
почтальонов

The postman Sila Silych will play a key role in the novel as he will share Ilya’s letters with Yakov (236–239). Another postman, Mikheev, also figures prominently in A School for Fools and is there also associated with the wind.

Почтальон Сила Силич играет ключевую роль в романе, ведь он делится письмами Ильи с Яковом (236–239). Другой почтальон, Михеев, занимает важное место в “Школе для дураков”, где тоже сравнивается с ветром.

intratextuality self-reference
Людям твоим — блуждать в парке твоем, а ненастьям твоим наступать

Syntactic parallelism.

Синтаксический параллелизм.

rhythm
твоим

Presumably, God’s.

explanatory
комиссионных крылаток

An armless coat purchased on commission. Clothing motif.

Безрукавное пальто, купленное на комиссионные деньги. Изображено ниже:

motif
Марии

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
Марии — служить в высокой кирпичной башне

The connection between Maria and Orina is made clearer. In chapter 1, Ilya described how Orina was transferred to a brick tower (155).

Проясняется связь между Марией и Ориной. В главе 1 Илья описывает, как Орину перевели служить в кирпичной башне (155).

explanatory character
границы станции

станции

Railroad theme.

theme
акварельным ветром

Poetic image, the wind is compared to a painter’s brush.

register/style poetic device
словно звезда близорукого без очков

A not inappropriate description of the experience of reading Between Dog and Wolf.

Довольно точное описание ощущений читателей “Между собакой и волком”.

self-reference
сцепщиков

Workers who join train cars together. Also mentioned in chapter 1 (R156/E12) and Note XXX (R266/E206). Railroad theme.

Рабочие, сцепляющие вагоны. Также упоминаются в главе 1 (R156/E12) и Записке XXX (R266/E206). Тема железной дороги.

intratextuality explanatory theme
стрелочниц

Railway workers (female here) who oversee the changing of signs. Railroad theme.

Железнодорожные работницы, предвидящие изменение знаков. Мотив железной дороги.

theme
стрелков

Guards, as well as hunters seeking Maria.

Охранники, а также охотники за стрелочницей Марией.

explanatory
фиксатые

Having gold teeth, with steel “fixes” on their front teeth.

explanatory
фиксатые сцепщики

Sokolov explains: “That of the coupler is a very dangerous profession. In those years, desperate and degraded people joined the couplers, many of them had a criminal record, some had been in jail for long. The time in prison undermined their health and, in particular, ruined their teeth. When released from prison, they had them repaired and covered by metal crowns. Many convicts had crowns on many teeth, but among serious thieves and criminals it was fashionable to have just one gold tooth. The gold-toothed couplers were treated with special respect and caution. At the beginning of her career Maria’s lovers were these gold-toothed couplers, that is, guys with a criminal bent, but when she became a supervisor, higher-ranking men began to approach her - machinists” (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

Соколов объясняет: “Сцепщик - профессия весьма опасная. В сцепщики в оные годы шли люди отчаянные и деклассированные, многие из них с криминальным прошлым, отсидевшие серьезные сроки. Сроки эти подорвали их здоровье, в частности, испортили им зубы. Выйдя на свободу, они чинили их, ставили металлические коронки. У многих сидельцев коронки были на многих зубах, но среди серьезных воров и бандитов модно было иметь фиксу лишь на одном зубе. К фиксатым относились с особым уважением и робостью. В начале ее карьеры любовники Марии были те самые фиксатые, то есть ребята с уголовным уклоном, а когда она стала начальницей, к ней стали приходить ухажеры более высокого ранга - машинисты” (личное сообщение, 7 июня 2023).

explanatory character
постепенно вытеснили степенные

Paronomasia (postepenno - stepennye).

Парономазия (постепенно - степенные).

sound
ветерану

The novel is set after World War II when many veterans returned to the Soviet Union bearing various injuries including missing limbs. This may also be a metaphor for an old train, perhaps from war times. Railroad theme.

Действие романа происходит после окончания Второй Мировой войны, когда ветераны возвращались в Советский Союз с разными увечьями, в том числе, с ампутированными конечностями. Также может служить метафорой для описания старого поезда, возможно, военного времени. Тема железной дороги.

explanatory theme
дальнего следования

Usually “poezd dal’nego sledovanija”, intercity train. Railroad theme.

theme
полушепотом, шепеляво

Alliteration (shep).

Аллитерация (шеп).

sound stylistic device
прохудившийся

Colloquial word: to become thin, leaky. The same word is used to describe boots (R153/E8) and a samovar (R187/E67).

Разговорное: испортиться, истончиться, протечь. Такое же слово используется для описания сапогов (R153/E8) и самовара (R187/E67).

intratextuality register/style

Also known as a coal-car, a railroad car that carries a locomotives fuel (wood, oil, or coal) and water. Railroad theme.

Вагон, предназначенный для хранения запасов паровозного топлива (дров, керосина, угля) и воды. Изображено ниже:

Тема железной дороги.

explanatory theme

Alliteration (shat).

sound stylistic device
шатуны

The mechanism on a piston engine connecting the piston to the crankshaft. Helps convert and transform the energy required to move the piston on a railway car. Railroad theme.

Деталь машины, механизма, соединяющая поршень с валом двигателя. Помогает преобразовывать энергию, необходимую для движения поршня паровозного вагона. Изображено ниже:

Мотив поездов.

explanatory theme
Деревьям

A possible reference to Lermontov’s poem “Na severe dikom stoit odinoko…” (На севере диком стоит одиноко…), a translation of Heine’s “Ein Fichtenbaum steht einsam”. This poem was translated by many poets (e.g. Fet, Tyutchev). Read the original and the translations here.

Возможная отсылка к стихотворению Лермонтова “На севере диком стоит одиноко…”. перевода “Ein Fichtenbaum steht einsam” Гейне. Стихотворение было переведено многими поэтами (например, Фетом, Тютчевым). Прочитать оригинал и переводы можно здесь:

intertextuality
напялившим

Colloquial: to put on (something that doesn’t quite fit).

Разговорное: надеть (обычно, не по размеру).

register/style
сумерек

Again, twilight — the central metaphor and time of the novel.

Вновь, сумерки — центральная метафора и время действия романа.

time theme
дирижерам

Personification of trees into conductors.

music poetic device
мукомолам

Sokolov will use the connection between torment (мука)/flour (мука) several times throughout the novel. The miller has already appeared once in chapter 1. The paronomastic stress on the words mukà/mùka (flour and pain, according to the accent) will be repeated many times in the novel, underlining the closeness of the two concepts.

Соколов несколько раз возвращается к связи между мукой (страданием) и мукой (хлебопекарной) на протяжении всего романа. Фигура мельника уже появлялась в главе 1. Скользящее ударение в словах мука/мука неоднократно встречается в романе, подчеркивая родственность этих понятий.

intratextuality symbol
Метель, о ком многие думали еще через я, тогда как особым указом его давно передали Зайцу, на кого и безухое оно столь походило, а несвойственное и ненужное Зайцу е передали метели, — она расходилась, разыгрывалась, делаясь неугомонной и неумолимой.

Метель (blizzard) was previously spelled мятель, as заяц (hare) was once spelled заец. In this section, as Martina Napolitano suggests, Sokolov plays with “the close pronunciation of certain unaccented vowels in Russian, which often gives rise to misspelling – я, е, й” (“Studyin This Volapuke” 289). Letters are transferred from word/concept to word/concept. The pairs metel’/miatel’ and zaits/zaets appear in connection with different linguistic phenomena: metel’/miatel’ reflects an alternative use of the vowel linked to the spelling instability still dominant in the nineteenth century and on which many authors, from Pushkin to Blok, played, also because of the possibility to reflect a different semantic intention (see Vasil’ev). Metel’, in fact, has its root in the verb mesti, to sweep, while that of miatel’ is to be found in the verb miastis’, to provoke smiatenie (confusion, disarray); in authors who make conscious and calibrated use of the two variants, it is precisely with this condition that the use of miatel’ is to be associated, as its strong expressive connotation prevails over the simple and objective identification of the natural phenomenon. Zaiats-zaets refers to the different outcome of the nasalised -e- of late proto-Slavic, which becomes, in East Slavonic, -ia- and, in South Slavonic, -e-: zaiats is, therefore, the more purely Russian form, while zaets reflects Slavonic-ecclesiastic outcomes and is therefore readable as a learned marker. The two pairs, which are never clearly defined as the object of discourse but whose (co)existence is taken for granted, are placed in correlation because Ilya imagines that miatel’ has surrendered the -ja-, useless to it, to zaets, who would have preferred it by virtue of the relatability of the form of the -ja-/я to a stylised, albeit earless, rabbit. In return, he would have ceded his -e-: the two forms of the modern standard, zaiats and metel’, would thus have been defined by their internal agreement, with extremely poetic and synesthetic characters due to the decisive role played by the graphemes themselves. This language play recalls the ancient Russian setting of the novel, whose plot seems to take place simultaneously long ago and in the years after WWII. Here, Sokolov also alludes to the story of how Alexander Pushkin, the father of Russian letters, encountered a hare on the road while on his way to support the Decembrist Revolt and took it as a bad omen.

Слово “метель” раньше писалось через “я” (“мятель”), тогда как слово “заяц” писалоьсь через “е” (“заец”). В этом отрывке, как предполагает Мартина Наполитано, Соколов играет с “неотчетливым произношением безударных гласных в русском языке, чреватым неправильным написанием я, е, й” (Napolitano, “Studyin This Volapuke” 289). Буквы передаются от одного слова-образа другому. Здесь Соколов также ссылается на историю о том, как Александр Пушкин, отце русской письменности, встретил зайца по пути на декабристское восстание и принял это за дурное предзнаменование.

Пары метель/мятель и заяц/заец фигурируют сочетаниями с разными лингвистическими явлениями: метель/мятель отражает альтернативное использование гласной, связанное с орфографической нестабильностью, присутствующей в 19 веке, которой пользовались такие великие писатели как Пушкин и Блок, частично благодаря возможности отражения разных семантических значений (см. Vasil’ev 2008 - VASIL’EV 2008: Vasil’ev S., “Metel’” ili “Mjatel’”? O zaglavii povesti A. S. Puškina, in «Russkaja reč’» 6 (2008), pp. 8-11, http://russkayarech.ru/files/issues/2008/6/02-vasiljev.pdf.). На самом деле, метель происходит от слова “мести” (метлой), тогда как мятель берет начало от глагола “мястить”, то есть вызывать смятение, хаос. Авторы, четко различающие оба варианта, безусловно, скорее придают слову “мятель” оттенок смятения, ведь выразительный подтекст слова преобладает над сухой характеристикой природного явления.

Пара “заяц-заец” относится к превращению праславянской назализированной “е” в восточнославянскую “я” и южнославянскую “е”; таким образом, “заяц” является более чистой русской формой, тогда как в слове “заец” отражается церковнославянское происхождение формы и (???). zajac-zaec refers to the different outcome of the nasalised -e- of Late Proto-Slavic which becomes, in East Slavonic, -ja- and, in South Slavonic, -e-: zajac is, therefore, the more purely Russian form, while zaec reflects Slavonic-ecclesiastic outcomes and is therefore readable as a learned marker. The two pairs, which are never clearly defined as the object of discourse but whose (co)existence is taken for granted, are placed in correlation because Ilya imagines that mjatel’ has surrendered the -ja-, useless to her, to zaec, who would have preferred it by virtue of the relatability of the form of the -ja-/я to a stylised, albeit earless, rabbit. In return, he would have ceded his -e-: the two forms of the modern standard, zajac and metel’, would thus have been defined by their internal agreement, with extremely poetic and synaesthetic characters due to the decisive role played by the graphemes themselves. This also recalls the ancient russian setting of the novel, whose plot seems to take place at the same time a long time ago and in the years after WWII

intratextuality structure
шансонетка

A diminutive form of the French word for song (la chanson) or a Russian song of various types include romances, sing-songwriter pieces, or criminal/prison songs. Here, it is used to refer to a female singer.

Уничижительная форма французского слова, означающего “песня” (la chanson) или русская песня различных жанров, включающих романсы, авторские и тюремные песни. Здесь, используется для описания певицы.

explanatory
Рисовать

Much in the chapters devoted to Yakov, his life, and his thoughts consists of ekphrasis—the literary device of describing in words a visual work of art—and other combinations of different genres and media. Here, for instance, the reader is asked to imagine the events of the chapter coming to life as if being painted before their eyes.

Значительную часть глав, касающихся Якова, его жизни и мыслей, составляет эксфразис — описание произведения искусства литературном тексте — и другие сочетания жанров и сфер. Здесь, например, читателю предлагается представить события главы как если бы они были нарисованы у него перед глазами.

Ostanin identifies this dam and reservoir as the Ivankovo Reservoir, also known as the Moscow Sea (24). Located on the northern Volga, in the Moscow and Tver Oblasts, approximately 81 miles (130 km) north of Moscow.

Останин определяет дамбу и хранилище как Иваньковское водохранилище, известное как Московское море (24). Расположено на севере Волги, в Московской и Тверской областях, приблизительно в 81 миле (130 км) от Москвы. Изображено ниже:

intratextuality symbol
Пейте и закусывайте. И сама пила и закусывала. Звали Марией. Машинист пил

Alcohol theme.

theme
Марией

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
Мариной

Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
дорожное, железное, скучное

According to Boguslawski, this is an allusion to Alexander Blok’s poem “Na zheleznoi doroge” (At the Railroad). Read it here. Railroad theme.

intertextuality theme
дорожное, железное, скучное

Enumeration.

Перечисление.

rhythm
переливая из Орехова в Зуево

Idiomatic phrase: переливать из пустого в порожнее (to chase one’s own tail, to mill the wind, literally: to pour from an empty (container) to the empty (one). Here, the phrase suggests the senseless of the engineer’s speech. The phrase is also an echo of a key idea of Yakov’s (the Binging Hunter) cited by Ilya in chapter 8: “Ain’t it wrong, he claims, to pour this year’s wine into an old barrel?” (R206/E99).

Идиоматическое выражение: переливать из пустого в порожнее (заниматься бесцельным и безрезультатным делом). Здесь указывает на бессмысленность речи машиниста. Эта фраза также относится к ключевой идее Якова (Запойного Охотника), процитированной Ильей в главе 8: “Не превратно ль, доказывает, вино сего года в старую бочку лить” (206).

phraseologism intratextuality
Орехова в Зуево

Orekhovo-Zuyevo is an industrial city in the Moscow Oblast, located approximately 53 miles (95 km) east of Moscow. The city was originally three villages—Orekhovo, Zuevo, and Nikolskoye—that merged in 1917. Here, Sokolov splits the name into two. Boguslawski suggests that “to underscore the meaninglessness and repetitive nature of the engineer’s speech, Orekhovo-Zuevo […] is changed into two separate towns” (235)

Орехово-Зуево — индустриальный город в Московской области, расположенный в 53 милях (95 км) к востоку от Москвы. Город был образован в результате объединения трех деревень — Орехово, Зуево и Никольское — в 1917 году. Здесь, Соколов разделяет название города на две части.

explanatory Russia location
буксы

A steel or cast-iron box that holds lubricants or bearings on a train axle. Railroad theme.

Стальная или чугунная коробка, внутри корой размещен смазочный материал и подшибник. Звязующее звено между колесом и рамой вагона. Изображено ниже:

Тема железной дороги.

explanatory theme
манометра

A device used to measure pressure.

Прибор для измерения давления. Изображен ниже:

explanatory
захлопывалось поддувало и открывался сифон

Signs requesting engineers close their trains’ siphens and dampers to avoid setting fire to wooden structures such as bridges used to line railways. Railroad theme.

Знаки, напоминающие машинистам закрыть сифон и поддувало, чтобы избежать вопламенения деревянных конструкций, например, мостов, соединяющих железнодорожные пути. Изображено ниже:

Тема железной дороги.

theme explanatory
поддувало

Here: damper, but can also mean mouth (as in “shut your mouth!”).

Здесь: зольник паровоза, но может также употребляться в значении “рот” (“захлопни поддувало!” — “закрой рот!”)

explanatory language
Рисовать

Much in the chapters devoted to Yakov, his life, and his thoughts consists of ekphrasis—the literary device of describing in words a visual work of art—and other combinations of different genres and media. Here, for instance, the reader is asked to imagine the events of the chapter coming to life as if being painted before their eyes.

Значительную часть глав, касающихся Якова, его жизни и мыслей, составляет эксфразис — описание произведения искусства литературном тексте — и другие сочетания жанров и сфер. Здесь, например, читателю предлагается представить события главы как если бы они были нарисованы у него перед глазами.

structure
темных плащей и зеленых шляп

People reduced to clothing. Clothing motif.

Here, for instance, the reader is asked to imagine the events of the chapter coming to life as if being painted before their eyes.

Значительную часть глав, касающихся Якова, его жизни и мыслей, составляет эксфразис — описание произведения искусства литературном тексте — и другие сочетания жанров и сфер. Здесь, например, читателю предлагается представить события главы как если бы они были нарисованы у него перед глазами.

structure
наяривала

Просторечное: производить какое-либо действие с особенным усилием, напряжением или увлечением.

register/style
тальянка

A type of Russian button single-row accordion that was particularly popular in northern Russia and in the Volga region in the nineteenth century. Although its name means “Italian,” this instrument was typical in Russia, Listen here.

Вид однорядной русской гармони, распространенной в северной России и Поволжье в девятнадцатом веке. Здесь, гармонь бвла произведена в Италии. Послушать можно здесь.

и венгерка ли, полька ли, то ли кадриль лупцевала трухлявые

Colloquial/low: to beat, thrash.

register/style

Colloquial: noise, hubbub, ruckus.

register/style foreign
отверстые

Poetic/archaism: open.

Поэтическое/архаизм: открытые.

register/style archaism
тряпьем

Colloquial: old clothes, rags.

Разговорное: старая одежда, тряпки.

register/style
тряпьем пастельных тонов — застиранным и дырявым — повисать на бельевых веревках, а после, сдутому ветром, разлетаться по парку стаями галок, ворон, рассаживаться по ветвям

A striking example of Sokolov’s transformations. Here, the chaotic noise of the pavilion’s environs is likened to raggedy clothing, which, in turn, is called to take flight, to move and hang on clotheslines and, finally, transform into birds. From the low rises up something beautiful (the pastel colors, the birds), and different senses are activated as the sound transforms into physical beings. Animal motif. Clothing motif.

Яркий пример характерных метаморфозов Соколова. Здесь, гвалт павильонов сравнивается со старой одеждой (тряпьем), которая, в свою очередь, вылетает, чтобы повиснуть на бельевых веревках, а затем превратиться в птиц. Убогое превращается в прекрасное (пастельные тона, птицы), при этом, задействованы разные чувства: звук превращается в живых существ. Мотив животных. Мотив одежды.

explanatory motif structure
пастельных тонов

The chapters concerning Yakov place a great deal of attention on colors. This is no surprise given how they frequently imagine scenes as if they are being painted before the reader’s eyes or observed in a gallery.

Главы, касающиеся Якова, обращают особое внимание на цвета. Это неудивительно, ведь в них часто предлагается представить сцены повествования, как если бы они были нарисованы у читателя перед глазами или выставлены в галерее.

structure
галок

Jackdaw. According to Chadd and Taylor, folklore suggests that “seeing a host of jackdaws can herald wealth or a new birth,” while “a lone bird can signal misfortune” (121). The jackdaw is also frequently associated with thievery, much like the magpie (Rowland, Birds 86). Animal motif.

motif
ворон

Crow. Crows, like ravens, are often associated with death (Armstrong 75). Animal motif.

theme motif
гомозиться

Low: to bustle, to fidget.

Просторечное: копошиться, возиться.

register/style
синюю

An echo of the blue book a few lines up as well as the “синька такая над Волчьей” from chapter 1 (154).

Отсылка к синей книге несколькими строками выше и фразе “синька такая над Волчьей” из главы 1 (154).

intratextuality sound play
Я люблю тебя, мой старый парк

A line from the song “My Old Park,” written by Vladlen Bakhnov and Iakov Kostiukovsky and made famous by Klavdiia Shul’zhenko. Read the lyrics (In Russian) here. Listen to a recording here. The song is a recollection of memories lived in the park, which recalls Ilya’s letter about living on the Volga. This line also encodes a reference to Afanasy Fet’s 1853 poem “The Old Park.” Read the poem (in Russian) here.

Строчка из песни “Старый парк”, написанной Владленом Бахновым и Яковом Костюковским. Стала известной благодаря Клавдии Шульженко. Слова песни можно прочитать здесь. В этой строке также скрыта отсылка к стихотворению Афанасия Фета “Старый парк” (1853). Прочитать стихотворение можно здесь.

music intertextuality
под лестницей

In one iteration of his life, Ilya will spend time under the stairs working as a furrier (R255/E187). Orina will visit him (or a man resembling him).

На определенном этапе жизни Илья проведет много времени под лестницей, работая меховщиком (255). Орина нанесет ему визит (или человеку, напоминающему его).

intratextuality
картонажного мастера

An allusion, as Ostanin notes, to Nikolai Gumilev’s 1917 poem “Answer Me, Carton Master” (Ostanin 24). Read the poem (in Russian) here. This poem depicts a tragic love story (or rather the poet’s infatuation) for a mysterious and unmerciful woman.

Как предполагает Останин, аллюзия к стихотворению Николая Гумилева “Отвечай мне, картонажный мастер” (Останин 24). Прочитать стихотворение можно здесь.

intertextuality
фантики от конфет

Candy wrappers appear three times in the novel (R160, 248, 262/E 19, 174, 199).

motif intratextuality
фантики от конфет

Anagrammatic assonance (fantiki-konfet).

Анаграмматический ассонанс.

sound stylistic device
Рисовать

Much in the chapters devoted to Yakov, his life, and his thoughts consists of ekphrasis—the literary device of describing in words a visual work of art—and other combinations of different genres and media. Here, for instance, the reader is asked to imagine the events of the chapter coming to life as if being painted before their eyes.

Значительную часть глав, касающихся Якова, его жизни и мыслей, составляет эксфразис — описание произведения искусства литературном тексте — и другие сочетания жанров и сфер. Здесь, например, читателю предлагается представить события главы как если бы они были нарисованы у него перед глазами.

structure
лик

Literary/archaism: face.

Литературное/архаизм: лицо.

register/style archaism
Марии

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
нередко вместо желаемого портрета неопытному рисовальщику — получать изображение как бы ее маски, и маска хотела проснуться, ожить, но мучительное летаргическое бессилие оказывалось сильнее вялых ее желаний — не просыпалась

An unsuccessful portrait produces a “lethargic” mask. The author invites the reader to consider the role of art in depicting life, nature, “reality”: what is the result of art’s imitation?

explanatory
зарницы

Maria (Orina) is frequently associated with nature, particularly weather. Mentioned in chapter 2 in connection to other body parts (R166/Е30).

Мария (Орина) нередко сравнивается с природой, особенно погодой. Упоминается в главе 2 в сравнении с другими частями тела (R166/Е30).

intratextuality explanatory character
тайного. Станет явным

An encoded reference to Luke 8:17: “Ибо нет ничего тайного, что не сделалось бы явным, ни сокровенного, что не сделалось бы известным и не обнаружилось бы” (“For there is nothing hidden that will not be disclosed, and nothing concealed that will not be known or brought out into the open”). Much in the novel, for instance, the sequence of crimes that lead to Ilya’s death, is not revealed until close to its end.

Скрытая отсылка на Луки 8:17: “Ибо нет ничего тайного, что не сделалось бы явным, ни сокровенного, что не сделалось бы известным и не обнаружилось бы”.

intertextuality bible religion
квозь сон услышишь, как во дворе шепотом забредит дождь-машинист

Alliteration (s, sh).

Аллитерация (с, ш).

sound stylistic device
как во дворе шепотом забредит дождь-машинист и вся земля, опьяненная, отравленная настоем осени Маша, горестно покорится ему, приемля его настырное мелкое семя

Nature (the rain and the soil/earth) is personified (or viceversa: the engineer and Masha) in this sexual intercourse.

Природа (дождь и земля) наделяется человеческими качествами (или наоборот: машинист и Маша) в этом половом акте.

symbol register/style poetic device
Маша
