A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
приемля

Dated/high (приимать): to accept.

Устаревшее/высокий стиль (приимать): принимать.

register/style archaism
тени ее бродить по стене

Assonance (teni-stene).

Ассонанс.

sound stylistic device
погремка

A neologism made from погремушка (rattle) and коробок (box).

Неологизм, образованный сочетанием слов “погремушка” и “коробок”.

neologism
папирос

A cigarette with a paper mouthpiece, typically without a filter.

Сигареты с бумажной гильзой, обычно без фильтра. Изображено ниже:

explanatory
Казбек

A famous brand of Soviet papirosy (a cigarette with a paper mouthpiece, typically without a filter). Mount Kazbek is also a mountain in the Caucasus near the Russian-Georgian border.

Рапространенная марка советских папирос (сигареты с бумажной гильзой, обычно без фильтра). Изображено ниже:

explanatory Russia
Казбич

A Circassian horseman in Mikhail Lermontov’s novel Hero of Our Time (1940). In the chapter “Bela”, the titular character’s brother, Azamat, offers his sister in exchange for Kazbich’s famed horse, Karagez. When he declines, Azamat conspires with the novel’s protagonist, Grigory Pechorin, to steal the horse, resulting in Bela’s eventual murder at the hands of Kazbich.

Черкес-джигит в романе Михаила Лермонтова “Герой нашего времени” (1940). В главе “Бэла”, брат одноименной героини Азамат предлагает Казбичу свою сестру в обмен на пресловутого жеребца Карагеза. Когда тот отказывается, Азамат сговаривается с героем романа, Григорием Печориным, украсть лошадь, что приводит к гибели Бэлы от рук Казбича.

intertextuality
если бы у него был табун в тысячу кобылиц, то отдал бы его весь за одного Азамата

A quotation from Lermontov’s A Hero of Our Time: “Если б у меня был табун в тысячу кобыл, - сказал Азамат, - то отдал бы тебе весь за твоего Карагеза.” In the chapter “Bela”, the titular character’s brother, Azamat, offers his sister in exchange for Kazbich’s famed horse, Karagez, whom he praises in this way. When he declines, Azamat conspires with the novel’s protagonist, Grigory Pechorin, to steal the horse, resulting in Bela’s eventual murder at the hands of Kazbich. Sokolov said the following of Hero of Our Time: “Geroi nashego vremeni [A hero of our time] is, arguably, the finest Russian nineteenth-century prose. That’s the point from which it all began. It is prose that cares about how it is made. It is self-conscious and self-reflexive. It admires itself; it knows what it does and how. It bewitches any reader ready to appreciate it” (Podshivalov, “A Conversation” 353). Read the original here and an English translation here. Animal motif.

Цитата из “Героя нашего времени” Лермонтова: “Если б у меня был табун в тысячу кобыл, - сказал Азамат, - то отдал бы тебе весь за твоего Карагеза”. В главе “Бэла”, брат одноименной героини Азамат предлагает Казбичу свою сестру в обмен на пресловутого жеребца Карагеза. Когда тот отказывается, Азамат сговаривается с героем романа, Григорием Печориным, украсть лошадь, что приводит к гибели Бэлы от рук Казбича. Соколов сказал следующее о Герое нашего времени: “Герой нашего времени является, пожалуй, величайшим произведением русской прозы девятнадцатого века. Это — отправная точка, с которой все началось. Эта проза, которая заботится о том, как она сотворена. Она самосознательная и самоотражающая. Она восхищается собой; она знает, что делает, и как она это делает. Она завораживает любого, кто готов ценить ее” (Podshivalov, “A Conversation” 353).

intertextuality motif
та девочка

An echo of “ta dama,” i.e. Orina, who haunts the riverbanks in search of a man (Ilya) and takes hunters away with her for three days.

Отголосок фразы “та дама”. то есть, обитающая на речных берегах Орина, которая ищет человека (Илью) и забирает с собой на три дня охотников.

character
юнгой

From the German Junge, a cabin boy.

foreign
матросы

Orina will encounter several sailors later in the novel. They will serve as rivals for Ilya.

Орина встретится еще с несколькими матросами позже в романе. Они станут соперниками Ильи.

intratextuality
качать на качелях

Alliteration (kach).

Аллитерация (кач).

sound stylistic device
веселых подруг

Boguslawski has identified this phrase as a reference to Nikolai Nekrasov’s 1846 poem “Troika”: “В стороне от веселых подруг?” Read the poem (in Russian) here. Read a translation here.

Богуславкий определил эту фразу как отсылку с стихотворению Николая Некрасова “Тройка” (1846): “В стороне от веселых подруг?” Прочитать оригинал можно здесь. Прочитать английский перевод можно здесь.

intertextuality
и с тобой, то и с тобой

Repetition.

Повтор.

rhythm
ни вечер, ни свет

That is, twilight, between dog and wolf.

То есть сумерки, между собакой и волком.

theme
Взвизгивала, словно чибисы в поле, когда идешь в полумраке через, расставив капканы на лис, дорожа настоящим, обещанным машинистом ружьем. Или когда юнга вел ее под руку к заброшенным стапелям, а чибисы летали, а стапеля загажены, а дожди и время не успевают смывать, и время от времени — то дохлая крыса, то палая жаба, то мертвый сорокопут. Марии — выть, выбегая на дамбу, зовя домой

Lapwings have traditionally been associated with misbehaving women (Rowland, Birds 97). Beryl Rowland describes the lapwing as “the most intelligent of the prophetic birds which attended King Solomon and it guarded his secrets” (97). José Vergara writes: “Maria/Orina is regularly correlated with deceptions and betrayal, often sexual in nature, so the reference to the lapwings has some internal logic. Her squealing evokes the folklore of the naughty birds” in key scenes throughout the novel (Vergara, “Flap” 367). Animal-human motif.

folklore motif
чибисы

Northern lapwing. Animal motif. Beryl Rowland describes the lapwing as “the most intelligent of the prophetic birds which attended King Solomon and it guarded his secrets” (Birds 97).

motif
полумраке

That is, twilight, between dog and wolf.

То есть сумерки, между собакой и волком.

theme
лис

Fox. Animal motif.

motif
юнга вел ее под руку к заброшенным стапелям

This scene of a sailor (in this case the cabin boy) leading a woman to an abandoned ship or slips will be repeated several times throughout the novel (R211-212/E108, R219/E123).

Сцена, в которой матрос (в данном случае, юнга) ведет женщину к заброшенному кораблю или пристани, неоднократно повторяется в романе (R211-212/E108, R219/E123).

intratextuality
стапеля

From the German/Dutch Stapel, boat ramp. Boat motif.

foreign motif
загажены

Colloquial: soiled, dirtied, polluted.

Разговорное: испачканный, грязный.

register/style
дохлая

Colloquial: dead, croaked.

Разговорное: мертвый.

register/style
крыса

Animal motif. According to Beryl Rowland, upon its appearance in Europe, the rat “quickly assumed the current symbolism of the mouse as a supernatural creature. Its nature gave it a reputation as a portent of evil, particularly in dreams, and incantatory charms were used to get rid of it” (Animals 136).

motif
палая

Dialectical: dead.

Диалектическое: мертвый.

register/style
жаба

Animal motif.

Мотив животных.

motif
сорокопут

Shrike, passerine bird. Animal motif.

Род птиц Lanius. Изображено ниже: Мотив животных.

motif
Марии

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
ветру-фонарщику

An echo of the postman, the wind-carrier, in Sokolov’s A School for Fools.

intertextuality self-reference
окна бараков: око

Paronomasia (okna - oko).

Парономазия (око - окно).

sound stylistic device
око за оком

Archaism/dated/poetic: eye.

Архаизм/устаревшее/поэтическое: глаз.

archaism register/style
взбодриться

Colloquial: to embolden, enliven.

Разговорное: оживиться, прийти в бодрое состояние.

register/style
с молодых-юных лет

According to Ostanin, a line from the popular Soviet song “The Orphan” (25). Listen to the song here. Read the lyrics (in Russian) here.

Согласно Останину, строка из известной совесткой песни “Сирота” (25). Послушать песню можно здесь. Прочитать слова песни можно здесь.

intertextuality music
кряхтя

Used at the end of this chapter to describe the artist (R161/Е20).

Используется в конце главы для описания артиста (R161/Е20).

intratextuality
на двух колесах

That is, on a bicycle. Recalls the bicycle imagery from Sokolov’s A School for Fools.

То есть, на велосипеде. Напоминает образ велосипеда в Школе для дураков.

Мария шила. Шила Мария

Various characters sew in the novel. In Yakov’s eighth poem, an oriole “resews evening into night” (R172/E39). Sewing is also mentioned in Note XVI (R200/E92). Yakov sews slippers (R274/E219). Sewing theme.

A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

explanatory motif
вселенский потоп

The mythical “great flood” (considered a divine punishment for men’s deeds) is common to many ancient cultures. The motif occurs, for instance, in Hinduism (Manu), Greek mythology (Deucalion), the Genesis in the Bible (Noah), the Mesopotamian tradition (Gilgamesh).

religion Bible intertextuality
в овраге

В овраге (In The Ravine) — a 1900 novella by Anton Chekhov. Chekhov’s text depicts the end of the patriarchal lifestyle in the Russian country under the pressure of industrialization. With this novella Chekhov moves from intellectual characters to factory workers. An intriguing interpretation was offered by Vladimir Nabokov in his lectures on Russian literature: he believed In the Ravine depicted “a world of deception, of mutual cheating” (Lectures 310).

“В овраге” — повесть А. Чехова 1900 года.

symbol self-reference theme

rhythm metrical pattern
Николаю

The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

отчет об охотах в облаву

To say, a valuable painting depicting the result of a hunting battue.

explanatory
возвращению охоты

A central motif in the novel, this phrase alludes to The Hunters in the Snow, a 1565 painting by Pieter Bruegel the Elder. The setting and action of this image recurs throughout Between Dog and Wolf (e.g., R202–203/E93–95), as they come to life in the text. Elena Kravchenko explains: “Besides the ‘trope’ of the exhibition viewing, the device of ekphrasis, and the ‘gallery’ structure of The Pictures, Sokolov borrows the underlying ‘teleology’ of Musorgskii’s work. Alongside Borodin, Balakirev, Cui, and Rimskii Korsakov, Musorgskii was one of the ‘Mighty Handful’ (‘Moguchaia kuchka’). Created under the patronage of an art critic Vladimir Stasov, it became the hub of a pioneering national style which espoused folklore and the traditions of the peasantry as the new foundation for Russian music. The group was closely connected with and drew inspiration from the Wanderers, an artistic movement […] Iakov is set to communicate a similar idea. He comes to the Volga to grasp and represent the lives of its people. Besides his poetic gift, Iakov is an artist, and it is his works that form the textual gallery of the prose chapters. The gallery ‘entries’ are either demarcated graphically with italics, which signals a title of a painting, or framed by a reference to their pictorial ‘origin’” (The Prose 61). She continues: “It can be argued that Iakov’s representation of human suffering, which constitutes one of the main themes of the novel, and which has been identified as the major moral message of many Brueghel paintings, is modelled not directly on Brueghel but on W. H. Auden’s ekphrasis in his ‘Musée des Beaux Arts’. Running through the images of Brueghel’s The Census at Bethlehem (1566) and The Slaughter of the Innocents (ca. 1564), it culminates in the ekphrasis of Landscape with the Fall of Icarus (ca. 1558)” (The Prose 63). On the presence and role of Bruegel’s imagery and subtext, see also Mario Caramitti’s article “Mul’tfilmy Breigelia.” Beyond these obvious ekphrastic connections between Sokolov’s novel and Bruegel’s painting, these are other points worth noting. For instance, the series from which Hunters in the Snow derives, The Seasons (1565) is divided into six paintings, five of which remain extant. “If a division of the year into six pictures seems strange initially,” Sabine Pénot and Elke Oberthaler write, “this proves to have been a common way of diving the annual cycle in the Netherlands during the period, as early spring and spring and early summer and midsummer were differentiated. The year’s inherently cyclic character relativizes the discussion around the ‘correct’ order of the pictures – which painting represents the beginning and which the end of the series” (214). Much the same may be said about the structure of Between Dog and Wolf, in which the poetic chapters trace the development of seasonal changes, while everything exists in an in-between state (seasons, characters’ identities, etc.). It is also worth noting that, as in Sokolov’s text where strict adherence to geographical reality is not observed, the landscapes depicted in the Seasons paintings are not accurate: “These so-called ‘mixed landscapes’ combine memories of the Alps with typically Flemish motifs” (229). There is something to be said about the way Sokolov, like Bruegel develops a “sheer inexhaustible richness of detail” that inevitably leads to “the limits of visual perception and linguistic representation” (215). One particular detail of the painting, apparently not described by Sokolov in the novel, feels relevant: “Thick icicles have claimed the mill wheel at the right edge and brought it to a halt, as though time itself has frozen” (228). Indeed, time and therefore the characters feel stuck in the world of Between Dog and Wolf.

Эта фраза, прямым образом относящаяся к центральному мотиву романа, ссылается на написанную в 1565 году картину Питера Брейгеля Старшего “Охотники на снегу”. Сцена из картины повторяется на протяжении “Между собакой и волком” например, R202–203/E93–95), будто бы оживая на страницах романа. Изображено ниже:

Е. Кравченко объясняет: “Помимо метафоры посещения художественной выставки, приема экфрасиса и “галерейной” структуры Картинок, Соколов заимствует основополагающую телеологию творчества Мусоргского. Наравне с Бородиным, Балакиревым, Кюи и Римским-Корсаковым, Мусоргский относился к “Могучей кучке”. Созданная под патронажем художественного критика В. Стасова, группа стала эпицентром развития нового национального стиля русской музыки, в основе которого лежали крестьянские традиции и фольклор. Могучая кучка была тесно связана и черпала вдохновение у художественного движения Передвижников […]. Яков намерен передать ту же идею. Он поселяется на Волге, чтобы запечатлить и отобразить жизнь тамошних людей. Помимо поэтического дара, Яков также наделен художественным талантом, и это его работы формируют словесную галерею прозаических глав. “Экспонаты” галереи или графически выделены курсивом, то есть, относятся к названию картины, или определяются отсылкой к “прототипу” образа” (Kravchenko, “The Prose” 61). Она продолжает: “Можно предположить, что изображение Яковом человеческого страдания, что является одной из главных тем романа и что было определено как одно из центральных моральных посылов картин Брейгеля, строится не напрямую на Брейгеле, а на экфрасисе У. Одена в его “Музее изящных искусств”. Останавливаясь на “Переписи в Вифлееме” Брейгеля (1566) и “Избиении младенцев” (пр. 1564), экфрасис достигает кульминации в описании “Падения Икара” (пр. 1558)” (Kravchenko, “The Prose” 63). О присутствии и роли образов и подтекстов Брейгеля можно прочитать в статье М. Карамитти “Мультифильмы Брейгеля” (Caramitti “Mul’tfilmy Breigelia”).

intertextuality intratextuality structure foreign
ибо

Literary/dated: because, for.

Литературное/устаревшее: потому что.

register/style
не обстоятельства ли определяют и обуславливают весь ход и облик явления

The narrator here suggests that it’s the circumstances determine a thing’s appearance, character, and so on, rather than the other way around. In other words, different contexts will generate different phenomena, much as the characters and settings in the novel shift depending on how their parts and configurations have been arranged around them. In short, a suggestion that art is self-defining.

Здесь рассказчик выдвигает гипотезу от том, что обстоятельства диктуют сущность происходящего, а не наоборот. Другими словами, разные контексты порождают разные явления, так же как герои и сцены в романе меняются в зависимости от сложившейся вокруг них ситуации и их прошлого. В общем, предположение состоит в том, что искусство определяет само себя.

explanatory
жароптицы

The mythical Firebird from Slavic folklore. Read the original here and an English translation here. In one version of the story, the Firebird transforms into a crow (as mentioned at the end of this sentence). Margaret Ziolkowski explains: “The bird resumes its fantastic form when Ivan returns safely home. Ivan’s father wonders what this transformation signifies, and the answer seems to be that the Firebird’s temporary metamorphosis into a dreary-looking crow is a symbolic consequence of Ivan’s betrayal by his brothers […] In Sokolov’s novel, many primarily sexual betrayals occur, but also a more wide-ranging metaphysical betrayal. The world portrayed in Between Dog and Wolf is marred by spiritual emptiness and pervasive cynicism, and the reference to the Firebird belies the loveliness of the landscape. The Firebird’s sad transformation is symbolically akin to the many images of physical and psychological maiming that occur in all three of Sokolov’s novels and point to the fractured and fragmented nature of existence” (414). Animal motif.

motif intertextuality folklore
сорок

Magpie. The magpie is traditionally known as a thieving bird: “Regarded almost universally as a symbol of ill-omen,” the “magpie’s incorrigible addiction to pilfering has no doubt contributed to its unpopularity” (Rowland, Birds 103–104). Animal motif.

motif folklore
сорок и ворон

Yakov mentions the magpie and crow in his eleventh poem, “Casting a Spell” (“Заговор”): “May the Magpie be sick, may the crow be sick too” (“У Сороки — боли, у Вороны — боли”) (R196/E84). Animal motif.

Яков упоминает сороку и ворону в своей одиннадцатой Записке “Заговор”: “У Сороки — боли, у Вороны — боли” (R196/E84). Мотив животных.

intratextuality motif
ворон

Crow. Crows, like ravens, are often associated with death (Armstrong 75). Animal motif.

motif
неотмирная

This place is also “out of this world” in the sense that it doesn’t exist; it is only a painting.

Это место “не от мира сего” в том смысле, что оно здесь не существует; это всего лишь картина.

That is, a visitor to the museum.

То есть, посетитель музея.

explanatory
рамы

At this point, the ekphrastic description of the Bruegel painting moves outward and encompasses the artwork’s frame as well. The reader (the visitor to the museum) pauses in admiration.

Теперь экфрастическое описание картины Брюгеля переходит к раме, обрамляющей произведения искусства. Читатель (посетитель музей) останавливается в восхищении.

explanatory
лессировки

Transparent or semi-transparent glaze with very little pigment is used in painting to alter how a layer underneath appears to the viewer.

Процедура, при которой картина прописывается тонким слоем прозрачной или полупрозрачной краски для видоизменения фона.

A private viewing before an exhibition is made open to the public.

Закрытый просмотр художественной выставки до открытия публике.

phraseologism time
пятисотлетье булавки

Ostanin remarks that this is a “mystery for the annotator” (27). Sokolov responds: “Sometime in the 20th century the pin turned 500 years old, probably English […] At some point I read about this in some journal […] Now I can’t find this information on the Net” (“Bol’shoe pis’mo” 126). As Caramitti noted in his dissertation, “the pin appeared in England in 1443” (130). Five hundred years later, Sokolov was born (1943).

Останин замечает, что это “загадка для комментатора” (Ostanin 27). Соколов отвечает: “Где-то в середине 20 века исполнилось 500 лет булавке, вероятно, английской […] Я в свое время об этом прочел в каком-то журнале […] Теперь не могу найти этой информации в Инете” (Ostanin “Bol’shoe pis’mo” 126). Как отмечает в своей диссертации Карамитти, “булавка появилась в Англии в 1443 году” (Caramitti 130). Спустя 500 лет родился Соколов (1943).

explanatory time self-reference
перст

Архаизм/поэтическое: палец.

Греческая богиня памяти и мать девяти муз. Изображено ниже:

Russia location setting
бубен

An instrument similar to the tambourine. The main difference is that some bubens have metal rings, plates, cymbals, or bells attached. Also mentioned in chapter 1 by Ilya (“брюзжи себе под дугою хоть до Валдай-пристани — литье бубенчиков” [R150/E2]) and in chapter 3 in one of Yakov’s poems (“Некто с бубном бредет пелесками” [R169/E35]).

Бубен — инструмент, напоминающий тамбурин. Основное отличие от тамбурина заключается в том, что у бубнам обычно подвешены металлические кольца или колокольчики. Упоминается Ильей в главе 1 (“брюзжи себе под дугою хоть до Валдай-пристани — литье бубенчиков” [R150/E2]) и в главе 3, в одном из стихов Якова (“Некто с бубном бредет пелесками” [R169/E35]). Изображено ниже:

intratextuality music folklore
Сумерки

Again, twilight — the central metaphor and time of the novel.

Вновь, сумерки — центральная метафора и время действия романа.

time theme
растаращили

Colloquial: to open eyes widely.

Разговорное: широко раскрыть глаза.

register/style
очи

Archaism: eyes.

Архаизм: глаза.

archaism register/style
згу

Word used in set expressions (зги нет, ни зги, зги не видать, ни зги не видать, ни зги не видно: что бы то ни было, Слепой слепого водит, а оба зги не видят) meaning that nothing is visible. According to Dal’’s dictionary, зга means “темь, потемки, темнота” (darkness). This definition presents a complication, as the phrase “ни зги не видать” would come to mean “no darkness is visible” (so dark that even the darkness is obscured). However, Dal’ also proposes that the word зга originated from “стьга” (path, road), which would make more logical sense in the various expressions that use зга. According to yet another version, Sokolov’s “favorite,” a зга is a ring on a yoke, which a driver couldn’t see in the dark (“Bol’shoe pis’mo” 126).

Слово, использующееся в выражениях “зги нет, ни зги, зги не видать, ни зги не видать, ни зги не видно: что бы то ни было, Слепой слепого водит, а оба зги не видят”, означающих, что ничего не видно. Согласно словарю Даля, “зга” означает “темь, потемки, темнота”. Такое определение вызывает некоторые затруднения, ведь тогда фраза “ни зги не видать” должна значить “не видно темноты” (так темно, что даже тьма становится невидимой). Однако, Даль предполагает, что слово “зга” происходит от “стьга” (путь, дорога), что придает больше смысла значениям со словом “зга”. Согласно еще одной, “любимой” версии Соколова, “зга” означает кольцо на упряжке, которое извозчик не видит в темноте (Соколов, “Большое письмо” 126).

language phraseologism
Посему

Dated: therefore, thence.

Устаревшее: поэтому.

register/style
кряхтя

Used earlier in this chapter to describe a ship boy (R163/Е25).

Слово использовалось ранее в главе для описания юнги (R163/Е25). Лодочный мотив.

intratextuality
амзтараханского

As Ostanin writes, “Amztarakhan (more correct Ashtarakhan, Aztarakan) — the capital of the Astrakhanskii khanate, which arose during the disintegration of the Golden Horde, located not far from the Itil’” (27). According to Boguslawski, “old Tatar names of today’s Astrakhan” (“Annotations” 236).

Как пишет Останин, “Амзтарахан (правильнее Аштарахан, Азтаракан) — столица Астраханского ханства, возникшего при распаде Золотой Орды, располагалась недалеко от Итиля” (27). Согласно Богуславскому, “старые татарские названия современной Астрахани” (“Аннотации” 236).

explanatory Russia location
многоножек

Myriapods (Ancient Greek μυρίος meaning “ten thousand” + πούς meaning “foot”) of the subphylum Myriapoda. Includes millipedes and centipedes Animal motif.

motif
увещевая

Dated: to urge, admonish, exhort.

Устаревшее: уговаривать, убеждать, заверять.

register/style
икоту перейти на безропотных страстотерпцев Федота и Якова

A reference to the saying “Икота, икота, уйди на Федота, с Федота на Якова, с Якова на всякого” (Hiccups, hiccups, go to Fedot, from Fedot to Yakov, from Yakov to everyone). This proverb derives from the folk belief that hiccups (a disease or demonic invasion) could be passed from one person to another. This hiccup (and the barrel further below) develops also the recurrent drinking theme. Although incidentally mentioned here at the end of chapter 2 through the allusion to a folkloric rhyme against hiccups (R163/E25), toward the end of the novel, Krylobyl, Ilya’s “spiritual” guide, is addressed by the poet in Note XXX (R206/E266), by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220), and by Ilya in chapter 17 as “Fedot Fyodorov” (R279/E227). The now dated name Fedot (or Fedoty, Theodotus) derives from the Greek and means “given by God (or Gods).” His patronymic (“son of Fyodor”) stresses this divine connection, as Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.”

Отсылка к поговорке “Икота, икота, уйди на Федота, с Федота на Якова, с Якова на всякого”. Происходит от народного поверья, что икота (болезнь или бесовское вмешательство) может передаваться от одного человека другому. Икота (как и нижеупомянутая бочка) превращается в повторяющуюся тему пьянства.

explanatory language theme intertextuality folklore intratextuality
Якова

Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character structure
бочку повествования

An image used several times in the novel to refer to the process and form of writing. See R206/E99 and R280/E230. Near the end of the novel, Note XXXV describes putting a bung back on a bottle of vodka (R272/E214). Alcohol theme.

Образ, неоднократно использующийся в романе для описания процесса и формы письма. См. R206/E99 и R280/E230. Ближе к концу романа, в Записке XXXV, говорится закрыть пробкой бутылку с водкой (R272/E214). Тема алкоголя.

intratextuality structure theme
затычку

Bung or spigot — a small peg or plug used to seal a cask or barrel. Alcohol theme.

Небольшой предмет для затыкания отверстия бочки. Изображено ниже:

Тема алкоголя.

explanatory theme
промозглого

Colloquial: cold and damp, inclement.

Разговорное: сырой и холодный.

register/style
философствовал

A word (verb, adjective) used repeatedly with connection to Yakov. See R163/E25, R189/70, R197/E86, R274/E219, and R277/E223.

Слово (глагол или прилагательной), неоднократно использующееся для описания Якова. См. R163/E25, R189/70, R197/E86, R274/E219 и R277/E223.

intratextuality character
Вита синэ либертатэ нихиль

Latin: Life without freedom is nothing.

С латыни: Жизнь без свободы — ничто.

foreign
Вита синэ либертатэ нихиль, философствовал он, виверэ эст милитарэ

Elena Kravchenko reads Yakov’s musings as an allusion to Mikhail Lermontov’s hero Pechorin in A Hero of Our Time who says, “I am prepared for all sacrificies except this one [marriage]; I’ll bet my life, even my honor, twenty times on cards […] but I won’t sell my freedom” (The Prose 68).

intertextuality
виверэ эст милитарэ

Latin: To live is to fight. A borrowing from Seneca the Younger, the Roman Stoic philosopher, statesman, dramatist, from his Moral Letters to Lucilius (96.5).

С латыни: Жить — значит бороться. Заимствовано у Сенеки Младшего, римского философа-стоика, драматурга, государственного деятеля, из его “Нравственных Писем к Луциллию”.

intertextuality foreign
Он был несвеж и немолод.

Yakov. A reference to the novel’s epigraph from Boris Pasternak’s Doctor Zhivago: “The young man was a hunter.” This line may also recall Esenin’s famous (last) words too: “There’s nothing new in dying now. / Though living is no newer.”

Яков. Отсылка к эпиграфу романа из “Доктора Живаго” Бориса Пастернака: “Молодой человек был охотник”. Напоминает последние слова Есенина: “В этой жизни умирать не ново, / Но и жить, конечно, не новей”.

intratextuality intertextuality
несвеж и немолод

Euphemisms.

Эвфемизмы.

stylistic device
.

The end of chapter 2 and chapter 5 were some of the earliest pieces of Between Dog and Wolf written. D. Barton Johnson reports: “This initial focus on Iakov, rather than Illia, emerges from the fragment of Mezhdu sobakoi i volkom that Sokolov to Carl Professor for the first number of Ardis’ new serial miscellany Glagol (1977). […] Much of this material, deleted in the final version, sets forth the book’s central theme of indeterminacy much more explicitly than anything in the final variant. The Glagol excerpt was abstruse and Proffer’s response was ‘almost complete incomprehension’ (letter to Sokolov of August 26, 1976). […] In his reply of August 15, 1976, Sokolov suggested that Carl Proffer’s doubts echoed his own. The material had been written under difficult psychological circumstances. He had wanted to parody various styles, but felt he had not succeeded. He now proposed that the fragment be published in Glagol but with the idea that it would remain suspended […] The excerpt’s opening and closing passages with their descriptions of Iakov and the excursus on his name/identity were deleted” (“Background Notes” 337–338). Along similar lines, author Tatyana Tolstaya has expressed frustration with the novel’s complexities: “Although it is a beautifully and very intricately crafted novel, the average reader cannot make it to the end and cannot recover its meanings. They are too secret. The reader does not feel like solving some of those crossword puzzles. […] It is ill advised to give readers tasks that are too complicated before they are capable of solving them” (Genis, “Lessons” 346–347).
